node.title: Installation of MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am trying to install MOOSE on macOS Catalina (old machine).
I installed Miniconda3, then, I noticed that the shell is "csh."
It is supposed to be "bash," isn't ?
Please let me know.
Sincerely,
Thomas

Catalina is supposed to be zsh (if it is a vanilla new installation of Catalina). It would seem Conda does not support csh.
My advice is either choose zsh or bash. You can modify your default shell in "System Preferences, Users & Groups, unlock the lock icon, right-click your user id, and click "Advanced Options".
Your default shell will be listed as "Login shell".

I am using bash.
on "conda activate moose,"
I got a message to do "conda init." Then, I did.
Now I got a message:
% conda active moose
zsh: command not found: conda
Could you tell what I did wrong?
Sincerely,
Thomas
Did you restart the shell or create a new tab in between conda init and conda activATE moose ?
Yes, because I was told to do so.

I mean I created a new Terminal window.
Sincerely,
Thomas
Can you look at your .zshrc and paste the conda initialization paragraph pls
Should look like in https://medium.com/@sumitmenon/how-to-get-anaconda-to-work-with-oh-my-zsh-on-mac-os-x-7c1c7247d896

I don't have the .zshrc file. I have .condarc
Sincerely,
Thomas

Conda should have created it if it didnt exist?
It should be in your home directory, so at ~/.zshrc
Either way it's a good idea to create it touch .zshrc and retry conda init (conda init zsh maybe?)

The prompt: % ... I believe is common for csh shells. It may be possible that that shell is still active? We can verify the shell interpreter by running:
❯ echo $0
-zsh
(mine is zsh)

I did "touch .zshrc" to create the .zshrc file.
when try "conda init", the message is:
zsh: command not found: cond
Should I do this under "bash"?
Sincerely,
Thomas

node.title: Moose commit history
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I noticed that the commit history of moose submodule in Bison app is different for different versions of moose. Of course the latest version of moose will have additional commits, but for the common time range some of the commits found in one version of moose are not present in the other version of moose.
I am wondering if someone could explain why the commit history for moose differ from version to version. I can provide additional information if needed; let me know.
Thanks,
Gyan

We utilize the method of continuous integration when developing MOOSE and the MOOSE-based applications (see this wikipedia article for more info). We update the software many times a day, and when testing passes for a change in MOOSE, we update many of the MOOSE-based applications on the same day once their tests pass with the changes to MOOSE. This allows us to get updates to applications as soon as possible, whether it be bug fixes or new features.
The master branch of BISON has its MOOSE submodule updated once all of its own tests pass with the new changes to MOOSE. With this, you can grab any commit of BISON, and have a version of MOOSE (noted within the submodule) that is guaranteed to be compatible.
This is why you will see the MOOSE submodule within BISON (and many other MOOSE-based applications) change quite a bit: we update BISON as soon as reasonably possible with newer versions (more recent commits) of MOOSE.
Bottom line: whenever you update an application, be sure to update the MOOSE submodule if it has one!

@loganharbour the issue @singhgp4321 is having isn't related to updating the submodule due to the continuous integration. It is due to commits that were in an older submodule of MOOSE are NOT found (the sha's are not shown) in the git log of the submodule in a NEWER version. Say we checkout a version of the BISON with a submodule of moose an update to the version of moose packaged with that version of the downstream app. Now lets say we take a version of BISON 3 days later and update to the moose submodule packaged with that version. If you go into the moose directory and do a git log in the newer version I would suspect all MOOSE commits to be the same as the older version plus any new commits in those 3 days. This is not the case. The old submodule will have MOOSE commits on say Jan 4. But then if you update to the new moose submodule in the newer version and the submodule git log shows zero commits on Jan 4. Why would the Jan 4 commit inside the MOOSE submodule be present in the older version of BISON but not the newest? The submodule should have been updated and new commits added, but old commits should not be removed.

git log doesn't return a linear in time history, are you sure the Jan 4 commits aren't just further down the log?
Either way if you have a specific example of a commit that is not longer there after a submodule update then we can look into it.

I'm pretty sure the sha was not found in one but found in the other. I'll have @singhgp4321  provide his example. I know the dates do not have to be linear if someone has been amending a commit over time and it gets merged. And Jan 4 was just an example but the same idea applies.

We never rewrite history.
The only time I could see this is an issue is with a manual submodule update with a commit that comes from a PR instead of within next/devel/master. Github is smart enough to let you use a sha from a PR when pulling from a repo. That sha could no longer exist.
It shouldn't be hard to write a quick python script to parse the log and find these. I don't know if this is the issue, but this is the only case I could think of. If this is indeed the problem, we should cause prechecks to fail if the hash isn't associated with moose/next.

That'd be great.
Just a side note that the dates are generally not linear, not just if commits have been amended. Rebasing for example will keep the original dates of your commits, yet place them all at the end of the log.

Here are the commit histories for two versions of Moose for two corresponding versions of Bison. You'll notice that Jan 4 commit shows up in one version's commit history but not in the other one: moose_commit_histories.txt

If you checkout 59f7e5b and look at the log you will find all the commits that are in your text file. You might have to go a bit far in the log, I recommend using git log --pretty=format:'%h : %s' > log.log
From git log at the first commit in your file, the January 4 commits in bold.
59f7e5b : Merge commit '44404267f136d11f3a09c8220ea98c6d4f809034'
4440426 : Merge pull request #16618 from lindsayad/check-leaks
96a63b8 : Merge pull request #16404 from crswong888/listing-improvement-16401
2e197b2 : Merge pull request #16588 from aeslaughter/reporter-declare-initialSetup-16586
3164e97 : Update libmesh
bb9d19b : Only populate attributes if supplied and reincorporate the attributes override into listing extension
310686b : Updated documentation for listing extension
9fc3b35 : created unit tests for listing extension
ba6897e : change names of 'prefix' and 'suffix' settings to 'prepend' and 'append' in extractContent() to avoid conflicts
56dd034 : Fix bug with float numbers - reset counter on every tokenization so that it doesn't accumulate during a live serve, which leads to higher and higher numbers.
aea2874 : Execute pre- and post-read methods for MooseDocsTestCase
3b70222 : Removing listing gold
ba54103 : more refactoring of listing extension
9f4a6a0 : Re-factor ability to remove blocks and params from hit files
e163c9f : listing extension can now exclude blocks and parameters that otherwise would be rendered
e572e43 : Merge pull request #16157 from lindsayad/isnt-prepared-mesh-api
eec233d : Merge commit '3877bd279e97bab2a579b926ecd33a543ea2fa2a'
211f7da : Initialize output lists for each call to output
e010c68 : Create test to demonstrate issue #16586
44a89d7 : Merge pull request #16570 from loganharbour/modules_unit
46327bf : Use MeshBase data to inform us when we should prepare
198485f : Add test
f9af866 : Merge pull request #16397 from lindsayad/auto-full-matrix-16396
3877bd2 : Merge pull request #16463 from cbolisetti/csvsampler
8444a70 : Merge pull request #16527 from milljm/16513-moose-pyhit-tlc
071d529 : Merge pull request #16475 from arovinelli/nl_forced_its
e5cb79c : Merge commit 'bbd2e27f25001c4834201d1d3ff5bb4fae46c84e'
bbd2e27 : Merge pull request #16597 from loganharbour/pandas_update
b319bbd : Resolve comparison warnings for stochastic tools unit tests
6b0743b : Resolve comparison warnings for porous flow unit tests
da567e7 : Resolve comparison warnings in geochemistry unit tests

Thanks Guillaume for the clarification! Yes, I do see the Jan 4 commits after going far down in the log; for some reason I could not view the log down enough earlier. Also, I am realizing that git log isn't the best way to look at the log. The pretty and graph arguments provide a much cleaner and clearer history of the commits.  git log --since "JAN 01 2021" --until "JAN 14 2021" --pretty=format:"%h %cd %s" --graph provides what I was looking for. Thanks!

node.title: Potential Build Issues
node.bodyText: Hey guys, I'm new to moose and linux and am having what I believe are build issues when trying to set up and run moose. I thought I had it installed correctly, but I kept getting a 'command not found' error when trying to run a simple make -j 4 test. going through the troubleshooting guide I ran into other issues, specifically my 'hello world' test also failed. What did I mess up?

Hello

You need to activate the conda environment every time you open a new console.
So ‘conda activate moose’.

Did you install in /tmp? Or was this for your hello world test?

Best
Guillaume
…
 Le 13 févr. 2021 à 03:35, ajyano22 ***@***.***> a écrit :

 ﻿
 Hey guys, I'm new to moose and linux and am having what I believe are build issues when trying to set up and run moose. I thought I had it installed correctly, but I kept getting a 'command not found' error when trying to run a simple make -j 4 test. going through the troubleshooting guide I ran into other issues, specifically my 'hello world' test also failed. What did I mess up?


 —
 You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.

Hello,
You're right, that was stupid of me. The hello world test is working now but still not the make tests? The /tmp was for the hello world test.

make command not found would indicate either your PATH is not set up correctly, or the necessary development tools on this machine are not installed. I am betting its the former PATH issue. Most Linux machines (if not all of them) come with make.
Can you verify what PATH is set to for us?
echo $PATH
Here's that path

Please refrain from using pictures of text. It prevents these forums from being searchable for others looking for answers. Simple copy paste of text suffices.
The path looks correct. Can you still not run make:
make --version

Good to know, thanks for the tip.
It's still not running the make command.
(moose) [aliyay@aliya-hpspectrex360convertible15ch0xx ~]$ make --version
bash: make: command not found
(moose) [aliyay@aliya-hpspectrex360convertible15ch0xx ~]$ cd ~/projects/moose/test
(moose) [aliyay@aliya-hpspectrex360convertible15ch0xx test]$ make --version
bash: make: command not found
What flavor of Linux are you using?
Manjaro

Looks like Manjaro is an Arch based distribution. You are going to need to install the development tools for that platform first. The first link I found is the following:
https://ostechnix.com/install-development-tools-linux/
Strangely, I don't easily find a "HowTo" page for Manjaro and software development. This page may also help, but it looks very Arch-linux centric: https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?id=61739
It's working now! That was it. Thank you for your help!

node.title: ld error while compiling tests on a cluster
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I just tried to update the moose installation on a local cluster, all ran fine (petsc and libmesh), but when trying to make the test I encountered a "strange" (== never seen before) error attached. Was wondering if anyone could point to a solution.

Thanks for any update,
Mauro

I think I mixed up moose directories. I was trying to install the newest branch but forgot to update the MOOSE_DIR accordingly and it install libmesh on my old installation.
Will try to re-install everything from scratch and re-open the post if I encounter any problem.
Sorry for that,
mauro

node.title: Linear and Powerlaw strain hardening question?
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Experts,
I'm new to the MOOSE environment and trying to run some Tensor Mechanics examples. I need to verify analytical solution of this paper "Plastic Relaxation of the Transformation Strain Energy of a Misfitting Spherical Precipitate: Linear and Power-Law Strain Hardening"  with moose numerical solution.  Can anyone suggest me where should I start? Is this sufficient to start with this examples projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/recompute_radial_return/isotropic_plasticity_finite_strain.i  and projects/moose/modules/combined/test/tests/power_law_hardening/PowrLawHardening.i ? Paper Attached in this discussion.
Earmme1981_Article_PlasticRelaxationOfTheTransfor.pdf
Thanks for the assistance!
Naveen
@hrishiv @albiedahal
If you are new to MOOSE, I suggest you start to read the Tensor Mechanics documentation, i.e. https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/IsotropicPowerLawHardeningStressUpdate.html
Thank you jiangwen84 let me go through this.

Hi Moose Experts,
I could create the input file for the problem as mentioned in the last post (for isotropic plasticity
), however the solution is not converging.
I have read this information here :https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/tensor_mechanics/Convergence.html
, but could not understand the process of setting up the convergence criteria?
Can someone please explain the convergence criteria in detail.
Thanks in advanced,
Naveen
JKlee_test.txt

Hi @jiangwen84 @
can you explain my above post in detail?
Thanks in advance
naveen

For mechanics problem, you have to use Global Strain system to setup strain periodicity. https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/GlobalStrainAction.html
Could you start with a simpler problem? e.g. 2D, without periodicity. Once successfully, add periodicity, and then 3D.
sorry about late reply thank you @jiangwen84. i will follow your instruction.

Dear @naveeniisc
I noticed you fixed the displacement only on one node, called boundary = 100
Can you try more standard boundary conditions for mechanics problems,
like constraining your cubic RVE in a corner,
something like:
[./z0_bot]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_z
boundary = back
value = 0.0
[../]
[./y0_bot]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_y
boundary = bottom
value = 0.0
[../]
[./x0_bot]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_x
boundary = left
value = 0.0
[../]
Convergence problems are likely to appear if you don't constrain properly your system.
Best Regards,
Nicolò Grilli
National University of Singapore
Dear @ngrilli  thanks for suggestion, let me try your solution.

node.title: How to print the output just before failed-solve ?
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am running a lengthy phase-field simulation where I print the exodus output for every 1000 iterations. After the a few thousand iterations, my simulations stopped because of "failed-solve".
Is there any way in which I can get the exodus file at the last time step before my simulation stops ?
I tried adding
[Outputs]
      [./end]
          type = Exodus
          execute_on= 'FINAL'
       [../]
[]

But it does not print *_end.e  file.
Regards,
Kamal
Give execute_on='FAILED' a try.
Thank you Andrew. I will try this.

node.title: Three concentration components diffusion model
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am modeling three concentration components diffusion (please see attached).
It would be appreciated if you could provide me with examples (suggestions).
Sincerely,
Thomas
Three_components_diffusion_model.pdf

Naively, this is just 3 decoupled diffusion equations, so you'd have three Variables, and three Diffusion Kernels and three TimeDerivative Kernels.
More interestingly, do the diffusion coefficients (D_{1-gas}, etc) depend on the concentrations in some way?  Are they scalars or tensors?  How about the source terms (g_{1}, etc) - are they constants, or do they depend on concentration?

Thank you, WilkAndy.
Yes, the diffusion coefficients and sources are actually a function of gas, c1, c2, c3, temperature, and time.
The diffusion coefficients are scalars.
But I would like to start the diffusion coefficients and sources as a function of gas and temperature only.
It would be appreciated if you could tell me where I look for the examples.
Sincerely,
Thomas

I don't think we have an example of this, but it shouldn't be hard to solve. I would begin by setting up the 3 diffusion equations as @WilkAndy suggested. Then switch over to using the Material system to compute the correct coefficients for each equation: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Materials/index.html

node.title: Phase Field - Grain growth - ACGrGrPoly
node.bodyText:
Hi!
Could somebody help me with the following?
I am trying to set up the simplest possible grain growth model (three grains) in the Phase Field module by combining parts of existing example files.
I append my input file (myTricrystalTripleJunction.docx); it runs well to the end but the results do not seem physically correct: the three order parameters even out to 0.3 over the whole model instead of being either 1 (grain) or 0 (no grain).
Can it be so that I need to modify the ACCGrGrPoly.C file? I noticed that the residual it returns is only d_F/d_eta. Firstly, there is no test function term and secondly there is no parameter L like in the manual (Basic Phase Field Equations). L only appear later in the file for the offDiagonal jacobian terms. I append it in the Appendix.docx file.
Very grateful for help!
Best Regards
Etienne
Appendix.docx
myTricrystalTripleJunction.docx

Hi Etienne,
ACGrGrPoly is a class derived from ACGrGrBase, which is in turn derived from ACBulk. Multiplying by the Allen-Cahn mobility L actually is done in ACBulk in the function precomputeQpResidual. ACBulk is a then a derived class of KernelValue. Multiplying by the test function is done in KernelValue.
To get started with a grain-growth simulation, I'd suggest using one of the example input files in the MOOSE repository and changing parameters for your problem, rather than trying to create your own input file. The simplest to start with is probably moose/modules/phase_field/examples/grain_growth/grain_growth_2D_random.i. You can change the number of order parameters using the global parameter op_num and change initial conditions to what you prefer. This example uses the Action system to add all the required kernels and materials to obtain the evolution equations.
As far as the non-physical behavior you were seeing, I looked quickly at your input file and I think the problem is at least partially coming from the fact that you are specifying v = 'eta0 eta1 eta2' as a GlobalParam. Each ACGrGrPoly kernel needs v specified, and it needs to be a list of all the other order parameters in the system besides the nonlinear variable for that kernel. For example in the ACGrGrPoly kernel for variable = eta0, you would specify v = 'eta1 eta2'. With v specified as a GlobalParam you end up with extra terms in your evolution equations which do not give the correct physics. For these reasons I'd suggest you start with the example from the paragraph above which uses the action system to fill in the correct kernels and parameters specified to each one.

Dear Larry,
Thank you very much for your detailed answer! I really appreciate you took the time to go through the relation between all the classes you mentioned.
I have now looked at grain_growth_2D_random.i and even at grain_growth_2D_voronoi.i and I will now try to understand how the Action system works.
I have also modified my input file according to your advice. I define a different v-vector for each ACGrGrPoly and it works perfectly! Again, I am very grateful for your help.
Best Regards
Etienne
Great glad that helped!

Hi,
Could I get a little help with the appended example file: grain_growth_2D_random.i?
As I understand from the Grain Growth Model section of the Moose Manual, order parameters and kernels are automatically created by the Action system called GrainGrowthAction. I even found the files GrainGrowthAction.h and GrainGrowthAction.C.
What I do not understand is:


Where, in the grain_growth_2D_random.i, are the GrainGrowthAction files called? The name GrainGrowthAction is not present in the file. I guess these files are called implicitly but how?


When it comes to variables, only the name PolycrystalVariables is defined but neither a type nor an action, see below. I noticed that Moose crashes if the name PolycrystalVariables is changed and I noticed that there is a folder called PolycrystalVariables
(moose/module/phase_field/doc/content/syntax/Variables/PolycrystalVariables)


This folder contains a single file called index.md which contain the following single line:
!template load file=stubs/moose_system.md.template name=PolycrystalVariables syntax=/Variables/PolycrystalVariables
a) Is this index.md file called by the variable name PolycrystalVariables in the grain_growth_2D_random.i?
b) What does this index.md file do? I noticed there were a lot of theses files in the moose folder for example one below PolycrystalKernel and one below PolycrystalRandomIC and I do not understand what these two do either.
Very grateful for help!
Best Regards
Etienne
[Variables]
Variable block, where all variables in the simulation are declared
[./PolycrystalVariables]
# Custom action that created all of the grain variables and sets their initial condition
[../]
[]
grain_growth_2D_random.txt

Hi Etienne,


The kernels are created by the PolycrystalKernel action, which is called in the Kernels block of that file. The variables are created by the PolycrystalVariables action. This particular example doesn't use the GrainGrowthAction. The source code files for these actions are in the same directory as the GrainGrowthAction files.


The files with the .md extension are markdown files for the MOOSE documentation system. They are used to create the web-based documentation you see at, for example, https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/index.html. You shouldn't need to look at these unless you are creating or modifying documentation.

Hi Larry,
Thanks a lot for your answer! I understand now that these action files are called by the name of the variables and the name of the kernel.
Best regards
Etienne

node.title: How to set gravity in porous media "thm_example"?
node.bodyText:
Hi
Currently the example (modules/porous_flow/examples/thm_example/2D.i) does not consider gravity. I have attempted to set it by setting "gravity = '0 -9.8 0'. However, it seems the gravity effect does not appear--there is no difference in fluid saturation whether I set gravity on or off. I expect the gas phase would move to upper regions.
How can I correct this? Thank you!
Modified file  with following modifications:
[Mesh]
type = GeneratedMesh
dim = 2
nx = 50
bias_x = 1.2
xmin = 0.1
xmax = 5000
ny = 50
ymin = 0
ymax = 5000
[]
[GlobalParams]
displacements = 'disp_r disp_z'
PorousFlowDictator = dictator
gravity = '0 -9.8 0'
biot_coefficient = 1.0
[]

Oh, it is just due to I did not notice the setting of permeability field in the original 1D problem.
permeability = '2e-12 0 0  0 0 0  0 0 0'

node.title: BC setting between two computational domains
node.bodyText:
BC_setting_between_two_computational_domains.pdf
All,
I am trying to set up boundary conditions between two concentration diffusion computational domains which are a function of concentration and time (please see the attached file).
It would be appreciated if you could give me your suggestion(s) for how to set up these BC settings.
Sincerely,
Thomas

Hi Thomas
Let's take the Dirichlet BC for c1 in the center for an example:
I think you should create a new class that derives from DirichletBCBase. You can look at the framework/src/bcs/DirichletBC.C file for an example.
Then in that class you add c2 and c3 as coupled variables (named _c2 and _c3 for example)
-add them to the input parameters with params.addCoupledVar("c2", "the concentration of species 2")
-initialize them in the constructor
Then override the computeValue function from DirichletBCBase with your own function that defines the value that c1 should have on the boundary, based on the values of c2, c3
To introduce time as its own variable (and not through c23(t)), use _t. See SinDirichletBC.C for an example.
EDIT: Yaqi's got a point. Interface fits the use case more than boundary conditions.
Hope this helps,
Guillaume

Thank you, Guillaume.
I found the way to work. :)
I think you can consider InterfaceKernel, which essentially imposes boundary conditions weakly (Neumann) for both sides. I doubt directly using Dirichlet BC will work.

Thank you, YaqiWang.
I found the way to work. :)
